awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  Development of a Miniaturized Multiwell Plate Reader
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project will be an instrument that alleviates several current difficulties in the growth measurement of many microbes, especially anaerobic and other fastidious organisms. A large number of these species are naturally occurring in the human body, and have recently been shown to play critical roles in allergies, autoimmune diseases, dietary health, cancer, infection response, and more. The study of these species is considered by many to be the next frontier of modern medicine, especially as current approaches to managing infectious diseases, such as traditional antibiotics, appear to be losing effectiveness. However, current measurement technology is largely incompatible with the specialized environments and chambers in which anaerobic organisms must be grown. There is a large unmet need for better ways to measure anaerobic bacterial growth; this need is growing quickly as interest in the field increases. The ability to conduct high-throughput experiments in specialized environments will become critical as research into various human microbiomes accelerates, and demand for high-volume data grows. The existing market for high-throughput measurement devices is at least $300 million and growing.  This platform will allow for systematic studies of cell culture growth that can be accomplished easily and economically. 

This SBIR Phase II project proposes to develop and refine a miniaturized multi-well plate reader that measures optical characteristics of up to 96 cell samples for measuring growth of many microbial samples simultaneously. The continuing rise of systems and computational biology demonstrates a growing demand for large amounts of quantitative data, and the variety of microbes relevant to the human body necessitates such an approach. However, these measurement techniques are not universally accessible due to current instruments' complexity, size, and cost. This project will continue development of a miniature, simplified version of a device called a multi-well plate reader, expanding the availability of parallel growth measurement (and other metrics) to a wider array of researchers and environments. The first goal is to simplify the instrument's electronics, add an on-board display for clarity, and allow battery-powered operation. The next goal is to accelerate equilibration to any surrounding environment to allow proper functioning even in extreme conditions, by measuring a wide array of environmental variables at different points in space and time. The third goal is to solidify the device's mechanical aspects for reliability and stability in a shaker. Finally, this project will support the development of a fully-functional wireless interface for control and data management, allowing effective remote use in any environment.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Within the field of microbial research, the demand for high-volume data is rapidly expanding. A good example of this growing interest is study of the gut microbiome; many researchers and clinicians view the relatively untapped potential of this field as a key opportunity in the fight against healthcare issues such as antibiotic resistance, metabolic abnormalities, autoimmune diseases, neurodegenerative conditions, and cancer, among many others. High-volume phenotypic studies are necessary for adequate characterization of microbial behavior, but this approach is limited in standard anaerobic chambers required for gut microbiome culture. Anaerobic research is often done with limited samples or with dependence on genotypic data, which is, at best, an approximation for cell behavior, and is potentially misleading. As a result, it can be very difficult to identify and interpret nuanced effects of multiple variables, such as microbial interactions, metabolite availability, and (especially) exposure to drugs.

Anaerobic microbial research is just an example; the problems highlighted above extend far beyond anaerobes, to include any highly secure or sensitive laboratories with limited space, field research, and more. Cerillo set out to design a device to gather this phenotypic data in a way that would allow unprecedented portability and ease of use, to alleviate space concerns and enable its users to maximize their experimental flexibility. The company's guiding philosophy has always been to open doors for researchers, and provide scientists with enabling tools.

In Phase I SBIR 1647768 and Phase II SBIR 1831082, Cerillo designed the Stratus to facilitate all research involving microbial growth while specifically addressing the specialized requirements for research on anaerobic microbes. The Stratus has been used in general microbiology research, synthetic biology, and work requiring high-level biosafety containment. These possibilities are driven by the Stratus's convenience and ease of use in any environment.

In this Phase II SBIR, Cerillo further enhanced the functionality of the technology underlying the Stratus, to the point where it can now reliably perform an even wider variety of biological and biochemical assays and experiments. This tool will go on to impact thousands of scientists worldwide, in three primary ways:

  1. Laboratories with current space restrictions will now be able to conduct high-throughput experiments and improve the quality of their data, enabling more (and faster) discoveries.
  2. More researchers in each lab will have access to high-throughput measurement, rather than relying on bottlenecked large equipment.
  3. Laboratories who have never had a plate reader will now have an introduction point into high-throughput experimentation.

The Cerillo team is pleased to have been able to participate in this project and excited to continue bringing valuable innovations to the scientists on whom the world depends.
